docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER four years of trying, Congress may be close to passing patients' rights legislation. A conference committee will work to reconcile a Senate bill and a version that the House passed on Aug. 3 after the chief Republican sponsor, Representative Charlie Norwood of Georgia, reached an agreement with President Bush on the thorny issue of a patient's right to sue a health plan. The Bush administration had said that such lawsuits should be brought only in federal courts, where damages are rigorously limited. Mr. Norwood's earlier bills and the Senate bill would have allowed suits in state courts with no limits on damages. Under the agreement with Mr. Norwood, the House voted to permit suits to overturn denial of medical care to be filed in state courts. But damages would be limited to $1.5 million.

headline.main: FIVE QUESTIONS for CHARLES B. INLANDER; Patients' Rights: What's at Stake?

docs.abstract: Charles B Inlander, president of People's Medical Society, answers Five Questions on patients' rights legislation currently before Congress; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: He is safe most of the time. Use-a-condom safe. Protect yourself and your partner safe. Are you positive or negative safe?

headline.main: With Fears Fading, More Gays Spurn Old Preventive Message

docs.abstract: Special report AIDS at 20: Taking Risks; finds that increasing number of HIV-infected gay men in San Francisco, with fears fading, are sometimes putting themselves and possibly other people at risk by engaging in unsafe sex; more men practice barebacking, as unprotected anal sex has come to be called; in gay newspapers, condom use, once a rallying call, has become subject of controversy and debate; public health experts, 20 years after AIDS epidemic emerged in United States, face new and perplexing challenge: AIDS, one a bold and flamboyant killer, now seizes its prey more quietly; new treatments can keep disease at bay, and hypervigilance is no longer an easy sell; photos; chart shows increase in number of gay men in San Francisco who report having multiple partners and unprotected anal sex (L)
docs.snippet: He is safe most of the time.    Use-a-condom safe. Protect yourself and your partner safe.  Are you positive or negative safe?

docs.lead_paragraph: Children return to classrooms this fall amid an increasingly pitched battle over Ritalin and other drugs used to treat millions with behavioral and emotional problems in school. Some of Ritalin's competitors are breaking with 30-year-old international marketing restrictions to advertise directly to parents, selling the idea that drugs may be the answer to their children's problems in school. At the same time, state legislatures are moving to prevent schools from recommending or requiring that parents put their children on medication.

headline.main: SCHOOLS' BACKING OF BEHAVIOR DRUGS COMES UNDER FIRE

docs.abstract: Children return to classrooms this fall amid increasingly pitched battle over Ritalin and other drugs used to treat millions with behavioral and emotional problems in school; some of Ritalin's competitors are breaking with 30-year-old international marketing restrictions to advertise directly to parents, selling idea that drugs may be answer to their children's problems in school; at same time, state legislatures are moving to prevent schools from recommending or requiring that parents put their children on medication; charts show increase in sales and number of prescriptions of drugs called analeptics, which are used to treat attention-deficit disorders; table shows top analeptics; photo (L)

byline.original: By KATE ZERNIKE and MELODY PETERSEN

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration proposed today to roll back some of the protections for Medicaid recipients that President Bill Clinton put in place on the day before he left office in January. The new rules set standards for health maintenance organizations and other managed care plans serving poor people and the disabled under Medicaid.

headline.main: Easing of Clinton Medicaid Rules Is Sought

docs.abstract: Bush administration proposes to roll back some of protections for Medicaid recipients that Pres Bill Clinton put in place on day before he left office in Jan; new rules set standards for health maintenance organizations and other managed care plans serving poor people and disabled under Medicaid; Bush administration officials say they will give states more discretion in deciding how to achieve those goals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The mayoral campaign of Peter F. Vallone began broadcasting its first network television advertisement on Monday night. It is entitled ''Alongside,'' a reference to Mr. Vallone's long political career. Campaign aides described the ad, which is broadcasting on six stations, as Mr. Vallone's first ''mass communication'' with voters. PRODUCER -- Doak, Carrier, O'Donnell & Associates
